task.title: Design (Carliner's Tripartite Model)
task.shortdesc: There are three primary aspects and types of design, each of which function differently, and are applicable situationally.

taskbody.context: These aspects form from Carliner's tripartite model of communication design and are as follows:

step.cmd: Physical Design: concerned with access, viewability, and timing.
step.info: PD is about moving the reader/userâ€™s eyes to relevant content. For this reason, issues such as access (for example, headings), viewability (for example, video resolution, audio quality), and timing (for example, speed of the video, pace of the narration) are influential

step.cmd: Cognitive Design: concerned with accuracy, completeness, and pertinence.
step.info: The cognitive design concerns include accuracy (that is, whether the video contained any errors of fact or execution), completeness (that is, whether the video appears to cover all expected topics), and pertinence (that is, whether the video is edited to include only relevant information).

step.cmd: Affective Design: concerned with confidence, selfefficacy, and engagement.
step.info: Affective design touches on issues of comfort, engagement, encouragement, and motivation. Qualities that matter are: confidence (for example, whether the narrator inspires confidence in the outcome of the lesson), self-efficacy (that is, whether the narrator or content encourages users to believe in their ability to succeed), and engagement (that is, whether an attempt is made to capture and hold attention).
